title: PURE DECADENCE DESSERT
text:
We had a gathering in Las Vegas and for the final night get together we ordered a chiffon cake from Paris Baguette.
What a delicious and tasty cake. This will be our go to bakery each we return to Vegas.
Recommend stopping here and enjoying a very tasty dessert.

title: A SMALL PART OF VEGAS HISTORY
text:
We visited this attraction on 03/10 arriving about 1030. Admission price is $3/person which includes the small exhibition area in the visitor center, viewing of a short historical movie and the freedom to wander the grounds of the fort.
Only one building of the original fort remains to this day, located on the southeast corner, and there are a few exhibits inside but with very little signage to explain what you are looking at. This is the same problem within the visitor center. There is a piano and organ that have signs that say “Do not touch I am very old” but no information about the history of these two musical instruments.
The foundation of the ranch house was excavated and later filled back in and only a sign now marks the spot.
The small stream that runs in the same general location of Las Vegas creek is a replica of the original as the water was diverted to help supply the city of Las Vegas in 1905.
The employee in the visitor center/gift shop was very friendly and helpful.
Worth stopping and spending 30 – 45 minutes to learn a little about the history of the area before it became Sin City.

title: NOT FOR YOUNG CHILDREN
text:
While in Vegas we visited Fremont on the night of 03/08. It is less crowded during this time compared to pre Rona. No live bands were on the stage. Just street performers in their assigned areas.
There were very few freaks out compared to pre-Rona times. Also, the crowds were sparse and you could walk around without bumping into anyone.
The Chippendales were there in their photo booth and a couple pairs of scantily clad females available for photos, but overall, there were not a lot performers.
The zipline was operating and a had long queue. The overhead light show was very well done and the light show had a Peter Max vibe. But I did notice that a lot of the casino lighting needs repaired, quite a few incandescent and neon were out, giving the area a rundown feel.
It must be experienced once when you visit Vegas.

title: FACTORY/SHOWROOM/MUSEUM/GIFTSHOP
text:
We visited this attraction on 03/08 and got there just as the free tour was starting. The tour lasts a good hour. The history of the Shelby brand is enough of a draw for the tour, but the explanation of the cars you look at is a bonus.
After the indoor portion, you are allowed into the factory area in the viewer gallery to see the Shelby’s in various stages of completion.
Some of the cars on display are for sale with no price attached, but as they say, if you have to ask you can’t afford it. Co-located in the building is a gift shop.
Whether you are a Shelby or Ford fan or not, you must visit this hidden gem.

title: NICE HOTEL CLOSE TO THE STRIP
text:
We stayed at this property for four nights from 03/07 – 03/11. I made reservations through the properties website and was given the room I requested. However only on the 2nd floor. I recommend getting a 3rd floor room as the noise from above can be a problem.
This hotel/casino is located far enough away from the strip to be quiet, but close enough to walk to located far enough from the strip that it's quiet, but close enough you could walk to the strip if you so choose.
Every employee we encountered was friendly and helpful.
The rooms are very spacious and comfortable, furnished with a work desk, couch, end chair, kitchenette table w/2 chairs. There is a place for a microwave but you must request one to be delivered to the room. The room was immaculate upon checking in and after each daily maid visit.
The grounds are meticulously maintained and very inviting. There are two pools, the central large pool, and a lap pool at the exercise building.
There are 4 restaurants/cafes located on the grounds.
A couple minor annoyances prevent this from being a 5-star review. The shower head is on a large gooseneck and as such can not be diverted in a downward fashion. I am 6 feet and the lower half of my body could not get direct spray from the shower head.
The aforementioned lack of sound-proofing makes adjacent and hall noise an issue.
I don’t know if Nevada has legalized weed, but the smell is pervasive in certain locations on the grounds, though I did not smell any in the buildings.
The resort fee of $39/night plus tax is a little high for what you get in return. The resort fee doubled the price of the room. Room rate was 41.58/night. Total for the four-night stay with resort fee/resort fee tax was $362.08
Overall, I recommend staying here. It is a relatively comfortable and quiet location close to the strip.

title: A NICE RESTAURANT
text:
During our four day stay at the Tuscany we ate at Marilyns Cafe four times; breakfast twice, lunch and dinner once each. Service was consistently very good even with varied waitstaff. Rona restrictions are in place but once you sit down to eat you are able to remove your mask.
Since my last review it has again been remodeled and is very bright.
All four of the meals were very good and served hot. Probably the best of all was the lunch we ate. We had the Angus burger ($10.99) that was superb and cooked to perfection and the Beer Battered Cod ($12.99).
Overall the prices are reasonable, with a good waitstaff and very good food.
A great place to dine.

title: PATHETIC SERVICE
text:
We stopped here for a late lunch on 03/09 at 1445.
We entered the restaurant lobby area and had to wait 5 minutes before the hostess came over and told us it would be a 25 minute wait. We put our name on the list and were told we would have to wait outside as there were already 2 people in the lobby area. So we waited outside. After 25 minutes and still not being called I went inside to inquire when we could expect to be seated. I was told they were short staffed and it would be another 20 minutes. If it wasn’t for the wife having her heart set on Pancit Palabok and Halo-Halo I would have called it quits then. So back outside I wait. After the allotted 20 minutes I enter again and am told they are just about ready for us, again I was told they were short staffed. After an additional 10 minutes bringing the total wait time to just under an hour we were lead to a booth.
Inside the restaurant, there were three tables occupied and every other table was piled high with dirty dishes.
Our drink orders were taken along with the food order. We ordered Pancit Palabok ($11.99) and Halo-Halo ($7.99).
The food was delivered within 15 minutes but no drinks. So the waitress went back and got our drinks.
After eating, the waitress came over and asked if there was anything else. We said we are still waiting on the Halo-Halo. She had forgotten that item. We were never offered a refill on the drinks.
The overall impression of this restaurant is one of chaos and lack of good management. The tables that were full of dirty dishes when we entered were still full of dirty dishes when we left.
The floor needed cleaning as there were napkins and other items strewn about.
It just gave an impression of a lackadaisical attitude.
On the plus side the Panci and Halo-Halo were very good, but not enough to overcome the other failings at this restaurant.
Total for our meal was $43.31
I CAN NOT RECOMMEND this restaurant.

title: GAVE IT A TRY
text:
We had lunch here on 03/08 and plates were $10.99 each with an Iced Tea ($1.39) and water for a total tab of $23.37 before tip.
Due to restrictions in place the buffet is set up so you point out what you want and the waitstaff dishes it up and then hands you the plate.
The best thing I had was the coconut shrimp.

title: COFFEE SHOP
text:
Caffe Bottega is a small coffee shop located close to the casino. It serves up coffee along with pastry’s, bagels, and morning sandwiches. We had breakfast from here on March 9. Two 16 oz coffees ($2.99 each), 2 donuts ($1.99 each) and a bagel ($4.25) for a cost of $15.40.
Coffee and food was good, but the service is a little slow. The coffee is brewed into air pots then dispensed. I counted 14 pumps for each 16 oz cup of coffee. Looks as though they need new air pots that dispense the coffee a little faster.

title: GREAT FOOD, GREAT SERVICE
text:
We stopped here on 02/14 for lunch arriving about 1145 and after having our temperature checked were immediately seated. Service was very courteous, prompt and professional.
For lunch we had an antipasto of Prosciutto Crudo ($16). I had a 1 ltr San Pellegrino ($5), my wife had a glass of water and an Aperol Spritz ($13).
The Prosciutto Crudo was very tasty and fresh. It was served along with a home-made bread and balsamic.
For the entrée I had the Margherita Pizza also known as a “1982 – Italy wins the world cup” ($16) and my wife had the Casarecce Mamma Silvana ($18).
For dessert we split a very tasty cheesecake ($8).
We also ordered a 1985 – Angelo’s Dad Opens a Deli – “A Buttiga” Pizza for takeaway.
All entrees were very tasty and served very hot.
Overall a very enjoyable dining experience.
Price of the meal before tip $102.23.
A little on the steep side but in a prior review my title says it “You Get What You Pay For” The food, service and friendliness of owner and employees makes the price worthwhile.
Recommend stopping by for a nice Italian meal

title: NEWER PROPERTY
text:
We stayed here one night on 12/10. Checked in just prior to 1500 and the front desk was very friendly and helpful. On my profile I request a top floor away from elevator. I was assigned a 3rd floor room, but the desk clerk was able to move me to the 4th floor into a king suite. The lobby area is very spacious and clean.
The hotel rooms face north and south. The north rooms over look the theater and High School. Our room was a south facing room and had views of the freeway, and the Temecula Valley.
On Friday nights during football season if you have a room on the east end of the hotel it could be problematic if there is a home game. (noise and lights)
As this is a relatively new hotel it seems as though it could have been constructed a little more sound-proofed. The traffic noise from the freeway was very noticeable in the room.
In the room every thing worked, there are USB ports aplenty. The desk lamp has plugs for European style electrical devices. No bath tub in our room, just a shower which is nice. There is a large floor safe in the closet. This is by far the largest safe I have seen in an IHG property. The A/C and heating is not central but a window unit that is controlled from the wall thermostat. It rapidly heated and cooled the room
and kept it comfortable through the night and was quiet.
The television is a large screen with a lot of features, however the view your bill feature did not work (see photo)
Due to the ongoing virus, the breakfast dining area is closed, however breakfast is available as a take-out feature. You let the server know what you want, they pack it in a Styrofoam box and you dine in your room. The cheese omelet, sausage and cinnamon roll was hot and tasty. Also affected by the virus is the usage of the pool and fitness center. Only one person or family allowed at a time in either facility as was explained by the desk clerk. We did not utilize either amenity.
Located close by (a short walk) are numerous restaurants and a movie theater.
Overall, this was a very pleasant stay. All staff we encountered clerks, breakfast server, cleaning staff were all very friendly and pleasant. All the amenities worked fine. The only drawback was the freeway noise, which may be less noticeable in a north facing room.

title: GOOD BURGERS, A LITTLE HIGH PRICED
text: We decided to try this burger joint, take out as dine in wasnt available. We were surprised at the quality of the burgers. The prices were a little on the high side, but we will probably eat here again.

title: YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR
text: Thought we would try this pizzeria. We didn’t want to wait until delivery started at 1300, so we ordered online and picked up at the store. We weren’t disappointed, we had a 1982 and a 2000. Very friendly owners/staff and very tasty pizza, though just a tad on the high side but worth the price.

title: DECENT BUSINESS CLASS LOUNGE
text: We utilized this lounge on Dec 18, 2019 on our layover from ATH to SFO. There was a large selection of food and drink available. Bathrooms were very clean and all staff encountered were very friendly. Made for a nice respite from the hubbub of the main terminal

title: SMALL CENTRAL SQUARE
text: Located downtown Fira at the corner of Danzi and Maritou streets it is home to a decorated donkey and a host of souvenir shops. It is a nice place to park yourself, on one of the numerous benches, and just people watch. During the Christmas season it, along with the rest of the town is festively decorated.

title: IMPOSING MONUMENT
text: This memorial with statue atop a large pedestal is in the eponymous Campo of BASILICA SANTI GIOVANNI E PAOLO. The bronze horseman is Bartolomeo Collenoi, a mercenary who left money for the construction of this statue and was completed in 1488.

title: DELIVERY OPTION
text: with the stay at home in place, decided to try the delivery option. ordered online, $4.99 delivery fee. delivered within 20 minutes. order correct and hot. tipped the Doordash driver. overall a very good experience. total before tip with delivery and tax was $43. considering BBD doesnt normally deliver this was surprisingly easy and efficient.

title: JUST A SO-SO STAY
text:
It may be one block from Disneyland as the crow flies but is about a 15 – 20 minute walk down Walnut, cut through the Disneyland Hotel grounds, through Downtown Disney to the entrance area.
We stayed one night here. Upon check-in were given a room on the 3rd floor and when we opened the door the occupants, who were changing, were as surprised as us. Back to the front desk for a new room and were given a room on the 4th floor in a building further away from the front desk. No apologies from the front desk about the mix-up. The new room was OK but had to call maintenance, the TV did not work. Maintenance arrived quickly and fixed this problem. My profile requests a top floor away from elevator. We were on the 4th floor, across from the elevator.
Had coffee in the morning and the creamer was bad, every package just clumped in the coffee.
When reviewing the bill, found a charge for a long distance phone call that was from the original room we were given. After bringing this to the attention of Tony on the front desk, an adjustment was made to the bill to remove the long distance charge.
Parking is $18/day.
We most likely will not stay at this property again.
place: Holiday Inn Hotel & Suites Anaheim (1 BLK/Disneyland)

title: GREAT BOOKSHOP
text: A great place to browse for books, maps and other paper items handmade in Italy. The proprietor is very friendly and helpful and represents this company well. The covers for the journals are made in town just below the shop in an alley. It was fascinating to watch the marbled covers be created by hand.

title: UNDER RENOVATION
text: This church along Agiou Minas sits below the Orthodox Cathedral and is currently closed undergoing renovation. It is a white church with white dome and red trim around the doors and windows. There is a center entry portal with two flanking doors and the bell tower is empty. When I looked through the windows, the interior altar area is very ornate
place: Church of St. John the Theologian

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC NON-BLUE DOME CHURCH
text: Located along the caldera escarpment, this church affords a nice photographic foreground to the caldera. It is all whitewashed, with a 3-bell tower and a triangular mosaic over the entry door. We were in Santorini for 5 days and this church was never open.

title: CHURCH OF ENGLAND IN ATHENS
text: This Anglican Church located across from the National Gardens is constructed of stone and above the entry portal has a large stained glass window, above which is a small bell tower. In addition, around the church is very heavy foliage including numerous palm trees. We were unable to enter the grounds or church as the entry gate was shut and locked.

title: NOW A MUSUEM
text: This building sits adjacent to Hadrian’s library in the southeast corner of Monsatiraki Square. It was built during the Ottoman era and is currently utilized as a museum.
place: Tzisdarakis Mosque (o Moschea della Fontana di sotto)

title: CLOSE TO THE AGORA
text: This church is located between Hadrian’s library and the Roman Agora and close to the Ancient Agora. Rather unassuming from the exterior and the entry door was closed so we could not enter when we walked by. It has two bell gables and a large cupola.

title: ORTHODOX CHURCH CLOSED IN DECEMBER
text: Located in Fira this church is built atop the caldera with a commanding view of the ocean. The current church was completed in 1968 after being rebuilt due to damage from the 1956 earthquake. Above the entry portal is a fine mosaic and on the southwest corner of the property is an imposing bell tower. When we visited Santorini from 12/08 – 12/13 the gate was locked and main entry portal was boarded up, so we were unable to enter inside.

title: IN THE SHADOW OF ANCIENT THERA
text: The church of Panagia Episkopi, is Byzantine and was constructed in the late 11th century and rebuilt at a later date. It is located outside of the main town of Fira close to the town of Kamari. When we visited the gates on the wall were locked and we were unable to enter the grounds. There is a large parking lot in front of this church.

title: ROMAN CIVIC CENTER
text: This ruins is located on the north side of the Acropolis, close to the Ancient Agora and was funded by Julius Caesar and built in the late 1st century BC. The open marbled courtyard was lined with colonnades with shops along the eastern edge. A few of the remaining columns show a smooth surface with Ionic capitals. The main entry was through the Gate of Athena Archegetis and the secondary entrance was near the Tower of the Winds. The signage could be better, but if you take your time to read then explore, you can get a good understanding of this area.

title: TO HONOR THOSE FALLEN
text: Dedicated in 1932, this memorial is located on the western side of the Hellenic Parliament grounds across from Constitution Square. It features a large retaining wall with the sculpture of the soldier lying on the ground and a cenotaph below the sculpture. Centered on the cenotaph is an eternal flame. Members of the Presidential Guard guard the tomb.

title: TO HONOR THE GODDESS OF VICTORY
text: This temple sits at the extreme southwest corner of the Acropolis next to the Propylaia and dates from 420BC. What can be seen from the viewpoint on the Acropolis is the front façade, facing east, the 4 Ionic columns and the architrave, the frieze and the cornice (which is heavily restored). There is also a view of the interior of the temple building that is rather small and has no windows. Around the temple was a parapet, the sculptures of which can be seen at the Museum. On the western side of the temple, there are also 4 columns and porch, but no entryway.

title: FORMERLY THE KINGS PALACE
text: This parliamentary building, not open to the public, was built in the mid 1800’s and hosts the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in the courtyard. In 1929, it was decided that this building would permanently house Parliament. When we were staying in Athens, the façade facing Constitution Square was utilized as a giant video screen.

title: CONSTITUTION SQUARE - MUST EXPERIENCE AT NIGHT
text: This is the central square of Athens and is located across from the parliament building and home to a subway stop. It is a happening place at all times of the day, but must be visited at night. When we visited Athens from 12/13 – 12/18 it was decorated in Christmas finery. In the center of the square is a large fountain, which at night changes colors on a rotating basis. There are also a couple other fountains at the edges of the plaza.

title: RUSSIAN ORTHODOX CHURCH
text: This church located close to one entrance to the national garden was originally built in the 11th century and is the largest surviving Byzantine church in town. The interior is very dark, but loaded with many gilded icons and numerous frescos. NO PHOTOS ALLOWED INSIDE and there is an individual who sits inside the door to monitor the interior. So please respect their request and not take photos of the interior. The bell tower is not attached to the church building but sits a little distance from the church.

title: TALE OF TWO CULTURES
text: This triumphal arch, erected in the 2nd century AD, rests between the Acropolis and the Temple of Olympian Zeus near a busy street. Made of marble this two-tiered arch is about 60 feet tall and reflects both Roman and Greek culture. The arch is in typical Roman arch design while the upper section is reminiscent of a Greek propylon. Above the arch is a centered Corinthian portico with pediment, flanked by Corinthian pilasters all topped with an entablature. There are two inscriptions on the architrave, one on each side. It was said to be the boundary between the cities of Old and New Athens. The city pollution is taking its toll on this monument.

title: HERODEION (THE PAST LIVING IN THE PRESENT)
text: This Roman theater located on the slopes below the Acropolis was completed in 161AD and donated to the city by Herodes Atticus. It was then was sacked in 267AD, and later still incorporated into the Roman walls. Today it is still used as a musical venue, with seating for nearly 5000, used by many contemporary performers including the Taiko drummers KODO.

title: THE PLAKA
text: This old town section of Athens, located close to the Acropolis and within the boundaries of the Plaka you will see many souvenir shops, galleries, handcrafted clothing and shoes, bars, restaurants and kiosks selling traditional Greek cuisine.

title: TEMPLE RUINS
text: This temple, built on the site of a temple from 6th century BC, was completed in 131 AD. What remains today are 13 of the columns comprising the southeast corner of the temple. The 15 columns that remain standing are of the Corinthian design and one on the southwest corner has fallen to give an idea of how they were constructed. There is also onsite a portion of the Themistoklean wall from the 5th century BC.

title: POMPEII MARKET
text: Marking this building, located in the northeast corner and fronting the forum are 3 Corinthian columns with a portion of the entablature atop the columns. This building was a commercial area for shopping.

title: WORTH THE CLIMB
text: We visited this area as part of a group tour. The bus dropped us off in the large parking area at the entrance and we were given 70 minutes to climb to the summit and return. I made the climb up and back within the allotted time and I have two bum knees. It is a steep gravel path that if you climb a good pair of shoes should be worn, no sandals, flip-flops or high heels for a more comfortable climb. Once on top at the caldron, the views of the surrounding area are phenomenal. At the entrance, there is a gift shop and a small mini-mart. In addition, an individual will provide walking sticks free of charge, but a tip upon return is expected.

title: EUMACHIA’S BUILDING
text: This large building fronting the southeast portion of the Forum with a single entry portal that opens into courtyard area with remains of colonnades lining this area. In the back against the center wall, in an apse, is a pedestal upon which sat a statue of Concordia Augusta. There is not much left here but it can be seen as a very large building

title: TEMPLE OF VENUS
text: This temple is located in the extreme southwest of the park, close to the exit area and is a jumble of rubble. Not much to be seen here except for a solitary column and the hideous sculpture by Igor Mitoraj of “ the Daedalus”.

title: MODERN POMPEI
text: Even though Pompeii is known for the eruption of 79AD the Parco Archeologico comprises a very small area of the “new” Pompeii, that is a vibrant and modern city. Less crowded and cleaner than the larger neighbor Naples.

title: LARGE PUBLIC BATH
text: This is one of many baths located within the Pompeii complex, this dating from 2nd century BC. There were separate sections for men and women. Each bathhouse had a changing room, cold bath area, warm bath area then the hot bath area. In addition to a place for public function and relaxation, they provided a social setting. The interior of the building provides a look into how the systems worked and the ornate walls. One of the better-preserved areas in Pompeii.

title: CAPITOLIUM
text: Located on the north side of the forum, this ruins, with Vesuvius, as a backdrop was once home to the statues of Jupiter, Juno and Minerva. Remains of the temple sit upon a large foundation with twin stairways leading to the dais at the front of the temple, with a set of steps running the length of the façade for entry into the temple proper, topped by 6 columns. There are also remains of columns positioned on the long sides of the temple ruins.

title: TEMPIO DEL GENIUS AUGUSTI
text: This temple complex, also known as the Sanctuary of the Genius of Augustus, located on the forum has a single large entry portal that leads to the vestibule and the courtyard. The temple stands against the back wall on a large podium. The marble altar, decorated with reliefs on all four sides is centered in the courtyard. The scene that is best observed is of a ritual sacrifice of a bull. .

title: FANTASTIC SERVICE AND FOOD
text: We stopped here on 04/18 for lunch, on a tour, after climbing Vesuvius and prior to entering the Parco Archeologico. This place runs like a well-oiled machine. Lunch consisted of a free first drink (anything you wanted refills then cost), along with a fantastic salad and your choice of 3 types of pizza. If you have a party of 3 or more, I recommend getting one each of the 3 types of pizza and then sharing the different types of pizza. Service was flawless and we did not feel rushed to eat. There is also a small perfumeria in the lobby area.

title: WONDERFUL EXPERIENCE
text: Large archeological area that has been excavated to show life as it was during that fateful day in 79AD. This park is a UNESCO World Heritage site. The area is divided into 9 regions and each region has much to see and information to be gleaned. There are houses, shops, brothel, baths and much more to see. We took a 2-hour tour and I think you could spend a full day here and not see everything. We will be back to spend more time here, it is definitely, a must see.

title: OUT OF PLACE
text: This display of modern art seems inappropriate in Pompeii as much as his “fallen angel” in Piazza dei Miracoli in Pisa. . While we walked around the ruins, the only remaining “sculptures” we saw was “the Centaur” in the forum and “the Daedalus” as we were exiting the park. If they want to display this art, then keep it out of the Archeological Park. It detracts from the ruins.

title: LARGE THEATER
text: Still in use today as a venue for theatrical and musical performance, this theater when reconstructed in 80 BC could seat approximately 5000 spectators. It is a well-preserved example of Teatro’s during the Roman time. An interesting sidelight is the urinal along the walkway

title: SMALL THEATER
text: This is one of two theaters side by side in the southwest section of the ruins. This theater sat approximately 1500 people for performances aimed at the more educated residents of Pompeii. Just the orchestra area and a few rows of seats are accessible unlike the teatro grande. Overall a well-preserved structure.

title: SOCIAL, POLITICAL AND RELIGIOUS CENTER OF POMPEII
text: The civic center of the city, accessed by four main roads, the main feature of the forum was the Temple of Jupiter (dedicated to Jupiter, Juno and Minerva). Today, beyond the former location of the temple is a grand view of Vesuvius. This is a place to stand and ponder what life was like in 79AD prior to the eruption.

title: ARTIFACT REPOSITORY
text: Located on the western edge of the forum, this building with eight openings, arched at one time, was a fruit and vegetable market, but today they hold many artifacts from the Pompeii excavations. It also houses some victim casts of the eruption.

title: THE MAIN DRAG (Via dell'Abbondanza)
text: A main road running through Pompeii that runs from the east gate (Sarno) to the forum. It is the longest road in the ruins at nearly 1 KM. Situated along the route are ruins of the Stabian baths, major intersection with via Stabiana (which leads to the theater district), elite residences, houses, shops and workshops. If you have visited Pompeii you have walked on this road

title: HOUSE OF THE WILD BOAR #1
text: There are actually two houses of the wild boar. This is a review of the one on via dell'Abbondanza close to Via Stabiana. The other boar house is located along Vicolo della Regina closer to the forum. When we visited this area of Pompeii the gate was closed and locked and you could only look at the entryway which features a mosaic depicting a wild boar in the woods being attacked by two dogs. Around the edge of the atrium is a mosaic of a fortified city with gates and crenellated towers. Even without being able to enter this view of the mosaic is fantastic.

title: HOUSE OF ILL-REPUTE
text: Located along Vicolo del Lupanare (Alley of the Brothel). This whore house has 2 floors, the upper floor was the residence for the owner and girls and on the ground floor, 5 rooms, each having a stone bed. On the walls of the hallway is a visual menu of activities the clients could request. As in ancient time, there is a line waiting to enter this building. An interesting look into a part of ancient life that is overlooked.

title: ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE OF ROMAN BATH
text: These ruins sit alongside a busy thoroughfare in Athens, under a canopy and were discovered when a Metro airshaft was being sunk. The ventilation shaft was moved elsewhere. These baths date from the late 3rd or early 4th century AD and were expanded in the 5th century. If you are in the area of the National Gardens well worth stopping and looking down upon history.

title: OLYMPIC HISTORY
text: A stadium has occupied this location for 2500 years, when first used in 330BC for the Great Panathenaia games. The original stadium was found during excavations and the stadium was reconstructed using marble, true to the original stadium. The 1st modern Olympic games were held here in 1896. The stadium can be seen from the square in front of the open end, but the small cost (€5) to enter, with an audio tour included, is worth the price to be able to walk around the stadium and enter the permanent Collection of Torches and Posters of the Olympic games that is housed below the seats.

title: LIBRARY OF HADRIAN
text: This area is a large archeological site of a library complex built by Emperor Hadrian in 134 AD in the classical Roman Forum style. There is only one entrance, on the west end through a Corinthian columned propylon. Inside was a courtyard and the library itself was on the far east side, flanked by reading rooms and auditoriums. In the courtyard, area 3 successive churches were built in the 5th, 7th and 12th centuries. This is an interesting site to wander around and marvel at the size of the library. There is very good informational signage to allow you to understand what you are looking at.

title: CHAPEL OF SAINT GEORGE LYCABETUS
text: This small-whitewashed chapel, located atop Lycabettus hill, can be seen over a vast area around Athens. This Orthodox chapel, dedicated to the dragon slayer, rebuilt in the 19th century replaced a church dedicated to the Prophet Elijah. There is a marker inside the chapel on a portrait of Father Louloudakis. The bell tower sits a short distance from the chapel itself.

title: MIKRI MITROPOLI
text: This small domed cruciform Byzantine church from the late 12th century sits adjacent to the Metropolitan Cathedral of Athens. In 1841, the church was used at the National Library and after repairs in 1863; it was also dedicated to Saint Eleftherios. Built largely of marble the dome is the best-preserved and most characteristic example of the Athenian type. The frieze above the entry door dates from the 4th century BC.

title: ORNATE INTERIOR
text: We visited this Cathedral on 12/17. This church is the Cathedral church for all of Greece. As churches go it is relatively new, constructed in the mid 1800’s in the neoclassical and Greek-Byzantine style. Inside are the resting places of two saints. With the exception of the mosaic above the entry portico the exterior is rather austere, but the interior is very ornate.

title: PEDESTRIAN BOULEVARD
text: Created for the 2004 Olympics this pedestrian walkway, paved with cobblestones and marble slabs, connects some ancient sites and easily accessed near the Acropolis and Museum. It is lined with street musicians, vendors and interesting architectural residences.

title: FORMER MADRASA ENTRY PORTAL
text: This doorway is all that remains of an Islamic Madrasa from the Ottoman era. It operated in the 1700’s until converted to a prison. By 1915, all that remained was this doorway. This is located outside the Roman Agora across from the Tower of the Winds.

title: GREECE EXPRESSING HER GRATITUDE TO BYRON
text: Located close to the heart of the city, this monument sits at the crossroads of two major streets, on the grounds of the Zappeion Gardens. Resting upon a 10-foot tall round pedestal, Greece, as an allegorical and larger than life woman, expresses her gratitude to Byron by placing a branch of a palm over his head, a symbol of immortality. Byron is shown as a youth, wearing European clothes and boots. The semi-reclining male figure on the rear symbolizes the Greek nation under siege. Greece, as an allegorical woman, places a crown upon the head of Lord Byron. Byron

title: COMMERCIAL CENTER OF THE AGORA
text: This building was originally built in 150 BC as a gift to the Athenians on the east side of the Agora. The stoa is a large two-storied building fronted by a double colonnade behind which were rows of 21 shops on each floor. It was the commercial center for the Agora. It was destroyed in 267 AD and reconstructed in the mid 1950’s for use as the museum.

title: RELIGIOUS AND POLITICALLY SIGNIFICANT
text: This statue of the former Archbishop of Greece rests in the square in front of the Metropolitan Cathedral of Athens. He was the archbishop from 1941 to his death in 1949

title: PLAIN AND UNDERWHELMING
text: This little memorial rests in a small square next to Church of Sotera Lykodemos. The monument consists of a marble base, with marble pedestal atop which is a black chain being hoisted into the air by a red balloon. On the pedestal is a hashtag in both Greek and English.

title: ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM OF THE ATHENIAN AGORA
text: This museum, small as museums go, is located in the reconstructed Stoa of Attalos. This building was reconstructed for the specific purpose of housing artifacts found in the Agora. The ground floor is for public display of sculpture and large marble pieces and inside, what were the shops, are smaller items. There are some must see pieces within the museum, one of which is the grave of a young girl, buried in 1000 BC.

title: DROMOS
text: This roadway, the principal thoroughfare, runs from the Dipylon to the Parthenon, just about 1 KM. It was the processional way for Panathenaic festival parade. When you enter the Agora complex, you enter on the Panathenaic road and runs in front of the Stoa of Attalos

title: EXCELLENT SHOPPING EXPERIENCE
text:
This store is located in the heart of Plaka and George and his wife Giota are the friendliest shopkeepers I have ever met. They make you feel as though you are family. I highly recommend stopping in and chatting with George and his family. The quality of merchandise they sell is top-notch. I am glad we made their acquaintance.
This store is not to be confused with the other Dimos store around the corner.

title: PATRON GOD OF ORATORY
text: This temple to Zeus Agoraios was constructed in the 4th century BC and was moved to this location in the Agora during the rein of Augustus. It is roughly 30 x 15 feet and has 4 steps to ascend the altar on the northwest corner. The rest of the monument only has 2 remaining steps. Atop the south end of the structure rises a large single block of stone.

title: EPONYMOUS HEROES MONUMENT
text: This monument, what is left of it, rests between the Metroon and Altar of Zeus Agoraios. It is known as the Monument of the Eponymous Heroes. These 10 heroes, each represent one of the 10 tribes of Athens. The monument consisted of 10 bronze statues representing each hero.

title: ANCIENT ARCHIVES
text: This building, from the 2nd century BC, was the official records repository for the ancient city all protected by the Mother Goddess. Just the foundation of the building remains.

title: BYZANTINE CHURCH
text: This church, located close to the Stoa of Attalos dates from the very late 10th or early 11th century. When we visited on 12/16, it was closed and we were unable to enter. It is situated atop the Nymphaion from the 2nd century AD. It is the only surviving mediaeval monument standing in Athens.

title: TEMPLE OF HEPHAISTOS
text: This very well preserved temple rests on the edge of the Ancient Agora on top of Kolonos Agoraios hill and was possibly dedicated to Hephaistos (patron of metal workers) and Athena Ergane (patroness of potters and crafts). It was constructed around 450 BC and is an example of Dorian architecture, with 6 columns on the ends and 13 along each side. On the eastern pediment are scenes depicting the labors of Hercules.

title: WHEN IN ATHENS A MUST VISIT
text: We visited this site on December 16, and almost had the area to ourselves. This site from the early 500 BC era is a phenomenal place to wander. Originally utilized as a commercial center there are numerous temples, public buildings and various ruins to observe. The most striking is the mostly intact Temple of Hephaistos. Throughout the site there is very good informational signage explaining what you are looking at.

title: HOROLOGION OF ANDRONIKOS
text: The “Tower of the Winds”, created by Andronikos, in the Roman Agora was erected in 2nd century BC. Built of marble, octagonal in shape and about 4 stories tall it was originally a water clock and later utilized as a church. Around the outside of the building on the frieze are the personifications of the eight main directions of the winds. The building was excavated in the early 1800’s. When we visited on 12/16 the entry door was open and we were able to enter.

title: ANOTHER ROCKY BEACH
text: Located a short distance from Ancient Akrotiri this beach sits at the base of a large red bluff. When we visited on Dec 10, there was one other person on the beach and no services were available. As with most beaches on Santorini, it is rock strewn

title: CATHOLIC CONVENT OF DOMINICAN SISTERS
text: This convent is located across a narrow street from the Duomo, we visited twice during our stay and the chapel within the convent was closed both times, but the church was open. This is the oldest Catholic nunnery in Greece, originally founded in 1595. The current building dates from 1864, but was damaged and repaired after the 1956 earthquake. The church within the convent grounds is the Church of the Virgin of the Rosary was consecrated in 1825. In the sanctuary behind the altar is the icon of Our Lady of the Rosary with St. Dominic and St. Catherine flanked by statues of St. Joseph and the Sacred Heart of Jesus.

title: THE DUOMO
text: This small, almost tiny “cathedral” is located towards the north end of Fira, is the first Catholic cathedral on Santorini. It was built in 1823 but severely damaged in the 1956 earthquake; it was a 20-year restoration and was opened again in 1975. It has a central nave with 2 side aisles and 3 entrances. One of the side chapels is dedicated to the patron saint of the island, Saint Irene, (Santorini). The campanile was erected in 1893.
place: Cathedral of Saint John the Baptist

title: GREAT ATMOSPHERE, HOSPITALITY AND FOOD
text:
We stopped here for an early dinner at 1800 on 12/12, our last night on Santorini and I must say, what an enjoyable experience. It started from the warm welcome by Gus, the very convivial owner of the restaurant, to the service and the food.
For entrees we enjoyed the Prawns “beure blanc” and Chicken in lemon sauce. Both were delicious. For drinks a glass of house white wine, ouzo and a large bottle of water. For dessert, we were treated to a traditional Christmas fare. Quince glazed in a sweet red wine sauce, absolutely to die for. If you are in Fira, you owe it to yourself to stop here and enjoy a meal and the company of Gus. Total for this delectable meal €46,30.
